newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Cyprus market edges close to full automisation.
newsitem.headline: Cyprus market edges close to full automisation.

text.p: The Cyprus Stock Exchange (CSE) has shortlisted firms bidding to computerise the market in 1997, a senior exchange official said on Tuesday.
"We now want to move into screen-based automated systems," CSE chairman Dinos Papadopoulos told an international banker's conference in Nicosia.
"We are proceeding with the creation of a central depository system and we have shortlisted firms on the final choice," he said. Tenders closed on August 2.
The conference is being organised by the Bank of Cyprus to promote the island as a regional financial centre.
Automating the CSE clearance system to create the central depository and computerising the trading system at a later date will cut the settlement period.
Share prices are currently injected onto small screens and settlement is completed nine days after a transaction.
"This is working very efficiently now," said Papadopoulos. "Now the vast majority of CSE transactions are completed in nine days. That is the best we can do without an automated system."
The CSE plans to move toward settlement three days after a transaction.
The CSE started operating in March, replacing informal over-the-counter transactions under the auspices of the Cyprus Chamber of Commerce and Industry.
Forty one companies are listed on the exchange, with a market capitalisation of 2.5 billion dollars. Banking stocks account for 55 percent or 1.4 billion dollars
Papadopoulos said investment opportunities for foreigners are growing despite remaining restrictions: "We are firmly moving in the direction of liberalisation."
Foreigners can hold a maximum share capital of six percent in banking institutions, and up to 49 percent in all other companies after relaxations by the Central Bank of Cyprus this year.
